# Effective altruism is about **doing good better**
Effective altruism is a **research field** and **practical community** that aims to find the best ways to help others, and put them into practice.
[**Read our intro**](http://effectivealtruism.org/</articles/introduction-to-effective-altruism>)
The world is changing in important ways; we can contribute to real progress, but we must also reduce the new risks that come with it.
[See full version in context.](http://effectivealtruism.org/<http:/lukemuehlhauser.com/industrial-revolution/>)
## What is effective altruism?
Everyone wants to do good, but many ways of doing good are [ineffective](http://effectivealtruism.org/<https:/www.givewell.org/giving101/The-Wrong-Donation-Can-Accomplish-Nothing>). The EA community is focused on finding ways of doing good that actually work.
This led to many ideas like the following:
  * It’s critical to pay attention to how many people are affected by a particular intervention. When we do this, it seems that some ways of doing good are over 100 times more effective than others.
  * We should focus on problems that are [important, neglected, and tractable](http://effectivealtruism.org/<https:/80000hours.org/articles/problem-framework/>)
  * [We can do a lot of good with our careers](http://effectivealtruism.org/<https:/80000hours.org/>).
  * [New technologies might threaten to wipe out life on earth, and reducing this risk might be a key priority](http://effectivealtruism.org/<https:/80000hours.org/articles/existential-risks/>).
  * [Some sentient beings](http://effectivealtruism.org/<https:/80000hours.org/problem-profiles/factory-farming/>) are ignored because they don't look like us or are far away.


[**Read our intro**](http://effectivealtruism.org/</articles/introduction-to-effective-altruism>)

The Centre for Effective Altruism (CEA) is a non-profit organization based in Oxford, UK, that operates in the realm of effective altruism—a philosophy and social movement that promotes using evidence and reason to determine the most effective ways to help others. The CEA's mission is simple yet profound: to help you maximize the impact of your charitable efforts, whether through time or financial contributions.

The organization emerged from the effective altruism movement, which emphasizes the importance of evaluating charitable interventions based on their effectiveness. This approach isn’t just about recommending a charity but getting you to think critically about which causes are most worthy of your support. The goal? To make giving not just an act of kindness, but a strategic effort to make the world a better place, effectively and efficiently.

Founded in Y Combinator's W17 batch, the Centre for Effective Altruism currently has a lean team of 15 dedicated to various initiatives within this philosophy. The work includes facilitating a rich tapestry of educational resources—from introductory seminars and online courses to a wealth of articles, podcasts, and books geared toward empowering individuals to do more with their careers and charitable donations.

Among their notable projects and initiatives is the "80,000 Hours" program, which emphasizes the importance of your career in maximizing your positive impact. They also provide charity recommendations through the "Giving What We Can" community, striving to connect donors with high-impact organizations. 

The effective altruism community isn't just a singular entity; it encapsulates a diverse network of individuals and organizations globally, working collaboratively to address the world's pressing problems—ranging from global poverty to existential risks posed by emerging technologies. 

For more insights, references, and to get involved, you can explore their website at [effectivealtruism.org](http://effectivealtruism.org). The centre’s motto resonates throughout their work and philosophy: it's about doing good, better.
